New Records: Georgia qualified for the knockout stages of a major international tournament for the first time as an independent nation.
Kvaratskhelia scored the fifth-fastest goal in Euros history after 92 seconds, and Georgia became the first debutants to reach the last 16 since Iceland in 2016.
Key Match Events: Georgia took an early lead with Kvaratskhelia's goal after 1:32, the fastest goal in their Euros history.
Mikautadze converted a penalty after Silva's error to double Georgia's lead.
Portugal struggled to respond, with Ronaldo failing to score in the group stage for the first time in his career.
Pre-Game Insights: Georgia were seen as underdogs after a poor qualifying campaign but defied expectations with their victory.
Portugal fielded a young lineup with four players under 23, making it their youngest starting XI in Euros history.
Post-Match Reflections: Georgia coach Willy Sagnol rested Kvaratskhelia in stoppage time, confident in Mikautadze's ability to maintain the lead.
Portugal's manager Roberto Mart√≠nez suffered his first competitive defeat, ending a 12-match win streak.
Miscellaneous Highlights: Mikautadze contributed six dribbles and twice as many goal involvements as any other player, showcasing his influence.
Georgia's defensive efforts were highlighted by Guram Kashia's 10 clearances, more than any other player.
Others: The match was Georgia's first major tournament knockout stage qualification, marking a historic achievement in their football history.
